title.narrative: We Don cam Teenage Pregnancy Prevention in Sierra Leone

description.narrative:
Everyone is responsible to ensure that adolescent and young people are protected from any form of violence, abuse, exploitation, and neglect. The project wants to address and actively involve all those that share the responsibility to ensure that adolescent and young people can enjoy their right to sexual and reproductive health education and be safe from Sexual and Gender-based violence:
• 3,500 adolescents, boys and girls, young women, and men 10 to 24 years old and their parents accessing SRHR services provided through the project
• 20,000 adolescents and young people and members of the targeted communities involved in awareness raising sessions
• Personnel of service providers in the 10 chiefdoms (Link teachers, school counsellors, social workers, members of community-based structures – Local Police Partnership Board (LPPB), Chiefdom steering Committee, District steering committee, Peer clubs, Inter-religious Council,)
• Health care provider personnel (including doctors, nurses, midwives and community health workers) addressed through project activities
• Duty bearers [Line ministries, the National Secretariat for the Reduction of Teenage Pregnancy (NSRTP), FSU, Plice, Judiciary (Magistrates), DHMT]

While reproductive health issues are important, there is also a need to focus on women's general well-being issues of rape, sexual assault and domestic violence also are beginning to receive due attention in discussions of Women's Health. Women's groups have called for action against the gender insensitivity that is often displayed by police officers and prosecutors and the courts in handling cases of rape and domestic violence. Health education, screening and treatment for sexually transmitted diseases are culturally appropriate services for survivors of rape and generally have not been available. Women of all ages may be victims of violence and conflict, but adolescent girls are particularly at risk for a range of reasons including size and vulnerability. Overall, there has been slow progress in improving the health of women programs to promote the health of models through maternal and child care services and family planning services have been under quote by reductions in government expenditure in the health sector, shortages of drugs, scarcity of medical personnel and inadequate health infrastructure. Deteriorating environmental and economic conditions, the resurgence of all diseases and the rising incidence of AIDS could be reversed the modest gains in Women's Health . The government has ratified conventions and international legal instruments on women’s rights. Thanks to the government for enacting the Amended sexual Offences Act in 2019. Moreover, many women are ignorant of existence of laws that recognize their rights and can be invoked for their protection. Various systems customary law, religious ideologies, and cultural stereotyping have been used to treat women as minors in the law and household, with few women able to inherit property in their own names. Teenage pregnancy in Sierra Leone pose severe threat to girls and their wellbeing preventing them from maximizing their full potential. Girls who lack choices and opportunities in life or who have limited or no access to sexual reproductive health care and rights are more likely to become married and pregnant. The eradication of SGBV, the prevention of early childbearing and teenage pregnancy will contribute to the improvement of women's and girl’s health as well as their social and economic participation and the realization of their rights and institutionalization of gender equality. Young people especially girls who lack choices and opportunities in life, or who have limited or no access to Sexual Reproductive Health Rights, are more likely to be disadvantaged and could not maximize their full potential in life. The TPP 2.0 project is a multicomponent approach which will contribute significantly to the reduction of teenage pregnancy, Sexual Reproductive Health and Rights and end Sexual and Gender Based Violence against women and girls through CORDAID’s Security and Justice RBF approach, linking Survivors to the PSD vocational training program – to improve access to economic opportunity for women and girls and building safe communities by ensuring women and girls are aware of predators in their communities through technology, community activism and Police.

• To reduce the vulnerability of adolescent girls, young women and men to SRH risks, including their adoption of safer SRH health practices • To improve the policy and legal environment for the protection of women and girls • To improve economic wellbeing for women and girls • To strengthen the capacity of law enforcement institutions (police, chiefs) to enforce national laws, by-laws and policies affecting women and girls • To facilitate active involvement and participation of community and police in the campaign against Gender-based Violence and Teenage Pregnancy • To facilitate the formation of anti GBV and teenage Pregnancy clubs and increase understanding and awareness of GBV and SRHR

mailing-address.narrative: Grote Marktstraat 45, Den Haag, Zuid Holland, 2511 BH

description.narrative: Number of people benefitting directly or indirectly from activities or services established/enabled/improved within a Cordaid Health project/programme

Health Project Specific Indicators
Number of A functional database accommodating the quarterly verified quality and quantity results of the service providers
